Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Citizenship Judge's decision on residency requirement
Application_Facts: Ms. Hussein reported 1099 days of physical presence but had undeclared absences and inconsistent documentation
Defendant_Behavior: Failure to provide clear and consistent evidence of residency
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged failure to meet 1095-day physical presence requirement
Assessment_Factor: Physical presence in Canada over four years
Procedural_Issue: Adequacy of reasoning by Citizenship Judge
Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistent documentation and undeclared absences affected credibility
Evidence_Used: Residency records, application forms, supporting documents
Application_Basis: Accumulation of at least 1095 days of physical presence in Canada
Evidence_Assessed: Days of physical presence, travel records, documentation consistency
Relief_Sought: Granting of appeal and remand for re-determination
Governing_Rule: Applicants must have 1095 days of physical presence in Canada within four years
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of explanation from judge on how absences affected day count; insufficient analysis of evidence
Outcome: Appeal granted; case remanded for re-determination
Harm_Assessment: Unjustified denial of citizenship due to inadequate judicial reasoning
Cause_Description: Ms. Hussein's citizenship application was rejected due to alleged failure to meet residency requirements
Evidence_Handling: Judge failed to adequately assess or explain treatment of evidence
Misrepresentation_Element: Potential misrepresentation due to undeclared absences
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of citizenship appeal
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient evaluation of applicant's evidence by decision-maker
Decision_Rationale: Decision lacked adequate reasoning and justification
Evidentiary_Issues: Inconsistencies in residency documentation and unexplained absences
